Q1.

CAPM Alpha Across Stocks

Stock Beta E[R] (%)
A 1.48 10
B 1.42 13
C 0.97 10

You observe three stocks with betas and expected returns (table above).
Using Rf=3%, E[Rm]=8%, compute each stock‚Äôs alpha in percent (%).

‚úÖ Stock A
CAPM = Rf + Œ≤(Rm ‚àí Rf) = 10.4%.
Œ±A = E[R]A ‚àí CAPM = 10% ‚àí 10.4% = -0.4%.
Interpretation: Œ± > 0 ‚áí above SML (underpriced ‚Üí buy); Œ± < 0 ‚áí below SML (overpriced ‚Üí sell).

‚úÖ Stock B
CAPM = 10.1%.
Œ±B = 13% ‚àí 10.1% = 2.9%.

‚úÖ Stock C
CAPM = 7.85%.
Œ±C = 10% ‚àí 7.85% = 2.15%.

Q2.

Informed vs. Fad Followers vs. Passive: Who Earns Alpha?

In a market with 73% passive, 3% informed, and 24% fad followers, the informed trade a portfolio with Œ≤ = 1.68 and E[R] = 16%.
Given Rf = 5%, E[Rm] = 12% (MRP = 7%):

‚úÖ Informed Œ±
CAPM prediction = Rf + Œ≤(Rm ‚àí Rf) = 16.76%.
Observed E[R] = 16%.
Œ±informed = E[R] ‚àí CAPM = 16% ‚àí 16.76% = -76 bp.

‚úÖ Fad followers‚Äô E[R]
Within the trading segment (informed + fad), expected return must match the CAPM prediction for the counterparty exposure:
E[R]traded (CAPM) = Rf ‚àí Œ≤(Rm ‚àí Rf) = -6.76%.
Let weights inside the trading segment be wI=11% and wF=89%. Then:
wIE[R]I + wFE[R]F = E[R]traded ‚áí E[R]F = (E[R]traded ‚àí wIE[R]I)/wF = -9.6%.

‚úÖ Fad followers‚Äô Œ±
We evaluate Œ± against the same Œ≤ used by the informed portfolio (as in the textbook exercise). CAPM benchmark = 16.76%.
E[R]F = -9.6% ‚áí Œ±F = E[R]F ‚àí CAPM = -2636.5 bp.
Interpretation: informed earn positive Œ± (skill), the counterparty earns negative Œ±; the passive investor (market) earns zero Œ±.

Q3.

Skill, Fees, and Equilibrium AUM

A manager can generate Œ± = 2.7% per year up to $747m of capital; above that, incremental Œ± ‚âà 0.
The fund charges 0.7% on total AUM. Assume investors flock in until net Œ± = 0.

‚úÖ Equilibrium AUM
Dollar alpha at capacity: Œ± √ó capacity = 2.7% √ó $747m = $20.17m per year.
At equilibrium, investors add capital until dollar Œ± = fees:
fee √ó AUM = 0.7% √ó AUM = $20.17m ‚áí AUM = $2881m (rounded).

‚úÖ Fee revenue at equilibrium
Fee revenue = fee √ó AUM = 0.7% √ó $2881m = $20.17m per year.
Notice this equals the manager‚Äôs dollar Œ± at capacity: $20.17m.
Intuition: competition drives net Œ± to investors ‚âà 0; skilled managers capture the rents via fees.

Q4.

Cumulative Abnormal Return (CAR) Around News

A firm-specific news generates an event-day abnormal return = 0.59%, followed by 4 days with an average abnormal return of 0.09% per day.

‚úÖ CAR logic (in %): Sum abnormal returns over the window.
CAR = AR0 + ‚àët>0 ARt = 0.59% + 4 √ó 0.09% = 0.95%.

Interpretation: Under semi-strong EMH, prices should adjust quickly to news.
A post-event drift (positive or negative) may indicate delayed reaction or under/overreaction.

Q5.

Momentum Long‚ÄìShort

A momentum strategy buys past winners and shorts losers (equal weights). Next period: winners return 15%, losers return -1%; the strategy beta is Œ≤ = 0.08.
Assume Rf = 4%, MRP = 6%.

‚úÖ Long‚Äìshort return
Spread = E[R]winners ‚àí E[R]losers = 15% ‚àí -1% = 16%.

‚úÖ CAPM required return
E[R]CAPM = Rf + Œ≤ √ó MRP = 4% + (0.08) √ó 6% = 4.48%.
When Œ≤ is near zero, CAPM says the expected long‚Äìshort return should be close to the risk‚Äëfree rate.

‚úÖ Alpha
Œ± = Realized long‚Äìshort return ‚àí CAPM required = 16% ‚àí 4.48% = 11.52%.
If Œ± > 0 with Œ≤ ‚âà 0, momentum delivers returns not explained by market Œ≤ ‚Üí evidence of a factor or behavioral effect.

Q6.

Fama‚ÄìFrench‚ÄìCarhart Expected Return and Factor Contributions

Factor Beta Premium (%)
MKT 1.01 4
SMB 0.13 2
HML 0.13 0
Mom 0.08 1

Given Rf = 4%, the table shows each factor‚Äôs beta and premium.

‚úÖ Expected return under FFC
E[R] = Rf + Œ≤MKT¬∑MKT + Œ≤SMB¬∑SMB + Œ≤HML¬∑HML + Œ≤Mom¬∑Mom.
= 4% + (1.01)√ó4% + (0.13)√ó2% + (0.13)√ó0% + (0.08)√ó1%
= 4% + 4.04% + 0.26% + 0% + 0.08% = 8.38%.

‚úÖ Momentum contribution
Contribution = Œ≤Mom √ó Mom = (0.08) √ó 1% = 0.08%.

Q7.

Disposition Effect and Taxes ‚Äî Brazilian Threshold

Context (read this first):
In Brazil, stock sales are tax-exempt if your total proceeds from stock sales in the month are ‚â§ BRL 20,000. If your monthly proceeds exceed BRL 20,000, then all capital gains realized that month are taxed at 15%. (Losses do not trigger tax and can typically be used to offset gains, but here we focus only on today‚Äôs cash to make the comparison clean.)

This exercise compares two end-of-month choices to raise cash:

  • Sell the winner (a position with a gain) vs. Sell the loser (a position with a loss)
  • We deliberately set the same proceeds (S) for both sales so that any difference in after-tax cash comes only from taxes (not from different sale sizes).
  • This connects to the disposition effect: investors often prefer selling winners (to ‚Äúlock in gains‚Äù) and holding losers (to avoid realizing losses), but that behaviour can be tax-inefficient when the threshold is binding.

You will: 1) compute after-tax cash if you sell the winner,
2) compute after-tax cash if you sell the loser,
3) compute the advantage (loser ‚àí winner).
If S > 20,000, selling the winner may incur tax today, while selling the loser does not.

Leg Proceeds (BRL) Basis (BRL) Gain/Loss (BRL) Tax (BRL)
Sell winner (gain) 22796 17297 5499 824.85
Sell loser (loss) 22796 30974 -8178 0

Assumptions: One sale in the month, no other offsets, ignore costs; FIFO implicit.
Rule: If monthly proceeds from stock sales > BRL 20,000, all gains that month are taxed at 15%; otherwise, exempt.

‚úÖ Step-by-step (winner leg with a gain)
‚Ä¢ Check the threshold: Monthly proceeds = 22796. Condition: S > 20,000 ‚áí gains are taxable at 15%.
‚Ä¢ Compute tax on the gain (if taxable): Gain = S ‚àí basis = 22796 ‚àí 17297 = 5499. Tax = 15% √ó Gain = 0.15 √ó 5499 = 824.85 BRL. (If the line above shows 0, it means the sale is exempt in this scenario.)
‚Ä¢ After-tax cash today: Proceeds ‚àí Tax = 22796 ‚àí 824.85 = 21971.15 BRL.

Why this matters: If the threshold binds, selling a winner creates immediate tax outflow, reducing today‚Äôs cash.
‚úÖ Step-by-step (loser leg with a loss)
‚Ä¢ Tax on losses: Realizing a loss does not trigger capital gains tax now; the tax due on this sale is 0 BRL. ‚Ä¢ After-tax cash today: Proceeds ‚àí Tax = 22796 ‚àí 0 = 22796 BRL.

Why this matters: Selling the loser yields the same gross cash as selling the winner in this setup, but with no tax haircut today. (Separately from this exercise, a realized loss may be used to offset gains in the month/year depending on the rules in force.)
‚úÖ Interpret and connect to investor behavior
Because proceeds are equal (S for both legs), the difference in after-tax cash is purely the tax on the winner (if any):
‚Ä¢ Advantage = After-tax(loser) ‚àí After-tax(winner) = 22796 ‚àí 21971.15 = 824.85 BRL.
‚Ä¢ If S > 20,000, then Advantage = the winner‚Äôs tax amount.

Key intuition (disposition effect): Many investors feel tempted to sell winners and hold losers. Under the Brazilian threshold rule, when S > 20,000, selling the winner can be tax-inefficient today (you pay 15% on the gain), whereas selling the loser gives you the same cash without a tax haircut. This illustrates how tax rules and behavioral biases interact: sticking to ‚Äúsell what went up‚Äù may reduce your net cash today, even if it feels psychologically rewarding.
